Award.AwardTitle: Life-Maker-Space: Creating a hands-on environment for Undergraduate Biology Education & Next-Gen STEM Training through innovative design and Community Engagement
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the Life-Maker-Space incubator network is to create a unique learning environment for undergraduates to have a concept-to-creation-to-community experience, where they will learn biological principles in the classroom, design experiments to test hypotheses, prototype solutions for innovative ideas and create tools for implementation. Student learning will go beyond the classroom and involve engagement with the community and local schools to foster active exchange of resources, skills and experiences. This environment will be created through access to equipment from 3D-Printers to small electronics, via community-based workshops with designers, engineers and scientists, and opportunities to prototype designs developed in classrooms.

Maker-Spaces has been shown to encourage the drive for innovation and the production of novel tools. This Life-Maker-Space will provide a novel way to engage students in life-science education, where they will be exposed to hands-on innovation, design practices and technology. Undergraduate biology students will be provided with opportunities to work on real world applications through nuanced problem solving while collaborating with a wide range of people ranging from designers to engineers and community members. Undergraduates will learn to explain concepts to as well as collaborate with and mentor younger counterparts. This initiative will bring scientific work to the larger community and allow young students to interact with a non-academic audience in a "safe" environment. It will also allow students to think about how science fits within the larger context of the community.

A collaborative effort by the University of Puget Sound, the Tacoma Art Museum and the Science and Math Institute, The Life-Maker-Space will be a place where undergraduate and K-12 students can become innovators - applying their life-science knowledge towards developing novel instrumentation, prototypes and technologies that are affordable, educational and scalable. A shared space is envisioned where young life scientists will learn alongside engineers, designers and artists; an open space where knowledge and resources will be shared with the partners, local schools and the community; an innovative space - where new ideas will be tested and implemented.

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange/finalreport/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Life-Maker-Space grant was an opportunity to create a Makerspace on campus that would transform life-science education. We planned to create a space where students could use 3D printers, scanners, laser cutters and small electronics to create small devices, print out models and engage in prototyping ideas thereby allowing them to move from just consuming knowledge to creating knowledge.

With the grant we managed to procure devices like 3D printers, laser cutters, scanners and small electronics and invited experts in the field to organize workshops that were open to the public.

The impact of this grant has been truly transformative. We have been able to overhaulour curricula providing students with more hands-on practical experiences. The impact on curriculum has moved from beyond just biology (where students created sensors to monitor the environment, printed out models of skulls and body parts) to other disciplines such as mathematics (visualizing graphs through 3D prints), to chemistry (printing out electron microscopy images of ice crystal surfaces) to physical therapy (prosthetic device making) to computer science and the humanities. 

We have now managed to reach the community with many of these workhsops either through direct participation or via Facebook Live feeds. Over 100 community members have particpated in our open houses and the response has been tremendous

As a direct result of this grant, the University of Puget Sound decided to create a physical makerspace on campus and invest in infrastructure and support to keep the initiative going. This has led to the creation of a space in the library where the equipment is housed and is open to the public. Student and staff are trained to help others make use of the equipment and help faculty design courses around these equipment. This has now led the makerspace to be a shared, community space that is constantly used.

The workshops we have organized have invited artists and scientists from around the world. These workshops (open to students and the public) taught us to use small electronics like arduinos and makey makeys to interface with microorganisms or create assisted navigation devices; create glucose sensors using gels to test levels of sugar in drinks; extract estrogen from urine; harvest and grow microbes from our surroundings; create synthetic squid skin that can expand and change color etc. These workshops have been eye opening and helped us understand the equipment better and jumpstarted the vibrancy of the makerspace on campus.

In short, the grant has helped transform both the curriculum for biology and other disciplines providing hands-on practical experiences to students, as well as reach out to the community by creating a shared, collaborative space where we can innovate and have fun.
